instruction: Leaves show yellowing with purple margins, fruit development stops, and root tips brown. Problem identification?

instruction: Plants show wilting at tips, vascular browning ascending, and yellowing on one plant side. Diagnosis?

instruction: Fruit develops cat-facing with deep scarring, leaves show tip necrosis. What's the issue?
output: Cold damage <8°C during early fruit development combined with boron and calcium deficiency. Maintain minimum 13°C during fruit set, apply boric acid at 0.5ppm with calcium foliar, ensure proper heating.

instruction: Leaves show fine mottling, reduced size, and fruit with uneven color. Problem?

instruction: Leaves show interveinal yellowing progressing to white, overall chlorosis. Problem?
output: Iron deficiency from manganese excess >6ppm competing for uptake sites combined with high pH >7.6 and bicarbonate. Reduce manganese, acidify to pH 5.8-6.2, apply Fe-EDDHA at 4ppm, improve drainage.

instruction: Plants show leaf curling upward, brittle texture, and fruit with blossom end rot. Diagnosis?
output: Calcium deficiency from high ammonium >35% of total N competing for uptake combined with low transpiration from high humidity >90%. Switch to nitrate-based fertilizer, reduce humidity to 70%, apply calcium chloride foliar.

instruction: Leaves show water-soaked lesions, stem cankers, and bacterial ooze. Problem identification?
output: Bacterial canker from Clavibacter spreading through pruning wounds in humidity >85% and temperature 24-28°C. Apply copper hydroxide at 2g/L preventively, disinfect tools with 10% bleach between plants, remove infected plants immediately.

instruction: Plants show yellowing between veins on older leaves, leaf drop, and weak stems. Diagnosis?
output: Magnesium deficiency from excessive leaching in sandy substrate combined with calcium >270ppm and potassium >380ppm creating antagonism. Reduce irrigation frequency by 25%, rebalance Ca:K:Mg to 60:30:10.

instruction: Leaves show fine stippling, yellowing, and premature drop. Problem?
output: Two-spotted spider mite feeding combined with water stress from EC >4.2 mS/cm and drought creating favorable conditions. Apply abamectin at 0.5ml/L, reduce EC to 2.5 mS/cm, increase irrigation maintaining 65% moisture.

instruction: Plants show stunted growth, leaf cupping, and yellow mottling. Diagnosis?
output: Tomato chlorosis virus (ToCV) transmitted by whiteflies combined with nutrient deficiency from root damage. Control whitefly with cyantraniliprole at 0.5ml/L, remove infected plants, optimize NPK balance, improve root health.

instruction: Fruit shows blossom end rot, internal browning, and poor firmness. What's wrong?
output: Calcium deficiency from excessive vegetative growth competing for calcium combined with high salinity EC >4.8 mS/cm. Prune excessive foliage by 30%, leach reducing EC to 2.5 mS/cm, apply calcium-specific fertilizer.

instruction: Leaves show necrotic spots with yellow halos, defoliation from bottom up. Problem identification?
output: Early blight from Alternaria spreading in moderate humidity 70-80% and temperature 24-28°C combined with nitrogen deficiency. Apply chlorothalonil at 2g/L every 7 days, increase nitrogen by 18%, improve air circulation.

instruction: Plants show yellowing from margins inward, soft fruit, and weak stems. Diagnosis?
output: Potassium deficiency from sodium toxicity >130ppm in irrigation water combined with inadequate leaching. Use low-sodium water source, increase leaching to 35%, apply potassium sulfate achieving K:Na >18:1.

instruction: Leaves show white powdery coating, yellowing underneath, early senescence. Problem?
output: Powdery mildew Oidium thriving in 60-75% humidity with poor air circulation <0.3 m/s combined with excessive nitrogen >240ppm. Apply sulfur at 3g/L, increase airflow to 0.6 m/s, reduce nitrogen by 28%.

instruction: Fruit develops zippering scars, cat-facing, and holes at blossom end. What's wrong?
output: Cool temperature <14°C during early fruit development combined with high humidity >86% and boron deficiency affecting cell division. Maintain 18-24°C during fruit set, reduce humidity to 70%, apply boric acid at 0.5ppm.

instruction: Leaves show yellowing with dark green veins on new growth, stunted. Problem identification?
output: Sulfur deficiency from RO water without supplementation combined with nitrogen deficiency affecting chlorophyll synthesis. Add ammonium sulfate to 150ppm N and 70ppm S, or use magnesium sulfate for both Mg and S.

instruction: Leaves show silvering, bronzing, and fine webbing on undersides. Problem?
output: Severe spider mite infestation from prolonged low humidity <48% combined with temperature >31°C and water stress EC >4.5 mS/cm. Apply abamectin at 0.5ml/L, increase humidity to 72%, reduce EC, correct irrigation schedule.

instruction: Plants show interveinal yellowing progressing to necrosis on older leaves. Diagnosis?
output: Magnesium deficiency from excessive potassium >440ppm combined with high calcium >290ppm and leaching from over-irrigation. Reduce K and Ca, rebalance to 60:32:10 Ca:K:Mg, reduce irrigation frequency by 22%.

instruction: Leaves show yellowing starting from base, brown root tips, wilting. Problem?
output: Root rot from Fusarium combined with salt stress EC >5.2 mS/cm and nitrogen deficiency from impaired uptake. Apply Trichoderma at 10⁸ cfu/ml, leach heavily reducing EC to 2.3 mS/cm, increase nitrogen by 18%.

instruction: Plants show leaf margin scorch, fruit blossom end rot, stem cracking. Diagnosis?
output: Calcium deficiency from high salinity EC >5.5 mS/cm preventing uptake combined with rapid growth from excessive nitrogen >250ppm. Leach substrate to EC 2.4 mS/cm, reduce nitrogen by 42%, apply calcium chloride foliar 0.5%.

instruction: Leaves show mottling, distortion, and yellowing; fruit misshapen. Problem identification?
output: Cucumber mosaic virus transmitted by aphids combined with phosphorus deficiency from cold substrate <17°C amplifying symptoms. Control aphids with insecticidal soap, remove infected plants, warm substrate to 21°C, apply P fertilizer.

instruction: Plants show stunted growth, pale leaves, and root galls. Diagnosis?
output: Root knot nematode infection combined with multiple nutrient deficiencies from severely impaired root function. Graft onto resistant rootstock, apply Paecilomyces at 10⁸ spores/g, increase overall fertilization by 25%.

instruction: Leaves show water-soaked lesions, stem cankers, bacterial streaming. Problem?
output: Bacterial canker from Clavibacter entering through pruning wounds in high humidity >88% and warm temperature 26-29°C. Apply copper bactericide at 2g/L, disinfect tools with bleach between every plant, remove and destroy infected plants.

instruction: Fruit develops cat-facing, zippering, and blossom end holes. What's the diagnosis?
output: Severe cold damage <9°C during early fruit set combined with boron deficiency <0.15ppm and high humidity >87%. Maintain minimum 14°C during flowering, reduce humidity to 68%, apply boric acid at 0.6ppm with calcium.

instruction: Leaves show yellowing with purple undersides, slow growth, poor roots. Problem?
output: Phosphorus deficiency from very cold substrate <15°C combined with aluminum toxicity in highly acidic soil pH <4.8. Warm substrate to 21-23°C urgently, raise pH to 6.2 with lime, apply starter P fertilizer 12-55-10.

instruction: Plants show wilting, brown vascular tissue, and sudden collapse. Diagnosis?
output: Bacterial wilt from Ralstonia spreading rapidly in very warm substrate >29°C combined with high humidity >82% and wounds. No chemical control; remove infected plants immediately, sterilize area with steam, use resistant varieties.

instruction: Leaves show bronzing, severe defoliation, and webbing everywhere. Problem identification?
output: Catastrophic spider mite outbreak from extended drought stress EC >5.0 mS/cm combined with extreme heat >35°C and humidity <40%. Apply miticide urgently, increase humidity to 75%, reduce EC to 2.3 mS/cm, release massive predator population.

instruction: Leaves show interveinal yellowing becoming white, complete chlorosis. Problem?
output: Severe iron deficiency from bicarbonate >220ppm combined with pH >8.2, cold water <12°C, and manganese excess >7ppm. Acidify water to pH 5.5, warm to 20°C, apply Fe-EDDHA at 5ppm, reduce Mn, improve drainage.

instruction: Plants show wilting, black rotting roots, foul substrate odor. Diagnosis?
output: Severe root rot from Pythium and Phytophthora co-infection due to extreme over-watering and substrate saturation combined with very high temperature >30°C. Reduce irrigation by 70%, apply mefenoxam+metalaxyl, lower temperature to 20°C, replace substrate.

instruction: Leaves show extensive yellowing, purple stems, and no growth for weeks. Problem?
output: Extreme phosphorus deficiency from very cold substrate <14°C combined with severe aluminum toxicity in acidic soil pH <4.5. Warm substrate urgently to 22-24°C, raise pH to 6.5 with lime, apply high-P starter 15-60-10 immediately.

instruction: Plants show complete defoliation from bottom half, severe stunting. Diagnosis?
output: Advanced early blight from Alternaria combined with severe nitrogen deficiency and chronic water stress. Apply chlorothalonil at 2.5g/L every 5 days, increase nitrogen by 35%, establish consistent irrigation, consider crop termination if >60% defoliation.

instruction: Leaves show yellowing between veins on middle leaves, fruit small and pale. What's the diagnosis?
output: Manganese deficiency from over-liming pH >7.6 combined with high iron >4ppm competing for uptake sites. Lower pH to 6.0-6.5 with sulfuric acid, reduce iron application, apply manganese sulfate foliar at 0.4%.

instruction: Plants show leaf tip dieback, fruit cracking at stem, and overall wilting despite irrigation. Problem?
output: Calcium deficiency from sodium toxicity >160ppm in water combined with high EC >4.7 mS/cm preventing uptake. Switch to low-sodium water source, leach substrate heavily reducing EC to 2.4 mS/cm, apply gypsum for calcium.

instruction: Leaves show dark green color with downward cupping, fruit development delayed. What's wrong?
output: Excess nitrogen >280ppm combined with low temperature <19°C slowing metabolism and phosphorus deficiency from pH >7.3. Reduce nitrogen by 50%, warm environment to 22-24°C, lower pH to 6.2, apply phosphorus.

instruction: Plants show leaf silvering, distorted growth, and bronzed appearance on new leaves. Problem identification?
output: Tomato russet mite causing epidermal damage combined with thrips feeding and low humidity <52%. Apply sulfur at 6kg/ha avoiding application >28°C, control thrips with spinosad, increase humidity to 68%.

instruction: Fruit shows blossom end rot only on first truss, normal on upper trusses. Diagnosis?
output: Early season calcium deficiency from rapid early growth combined with underdeveloped root system and cold substrate <18°C. Warm substrate to 21°C, apply calcium foliar at 0.6% on young fruit, reduce early nitrogen to slow vegetative growth.

instruction: Leaves show mosaic pattern, fruit with brown rugose texture and malformation. What's the issue?
output: Tomato brown rugose fruit virus (ToBRFV) spreading mechanically combined with heat stress >33°C amplifying symptoms. Implement extreme sanitation with 10% TSP or Virkon S, remove all infected plants, disinfect greenhouse completely.

instruction: Plants show stunted growth, cupped leaves, and yellowing starting from older leaves. Problem?
output: Root knot nematode causing galling combined with magnesium deficiency from excessive potassium >460ppm. Graft onto resistant rootstock Mi-1.2, reduce potassium, rebalance to Ca:K:Mg 58:30:12, apply nematicide if needed.

instruction: EMERGENCY: Temperature spike to 38°C, plants wilting rapidly, cooling system failed. Immediate action?
output: Activate emergency shading at 60-80% immediately, start manual fogging/misting every 5 minutes, open all vents maximally, and apply foliar spray with calcium to reduce transpiration stress. Contact cooling system technician urgently while implementing manual cooling.

instruction: EMERGENCY: Fertigation system injecting at 10x concentration, EC spiked to 12 mS/cm. Immediate action?
output: Stop fertigation immediately, flush all plants with clean water at 200% of pot volume to leach excess salts, continue flushing until drainage EC drops below 4.0 mS/cm. Monitor plants hourly for next 24 hours; expect tip burn and temporary wilting requiring 3-5 days recovery.

instruction: EMERGENCY: Spider mite population explosion, entire crop at risk. What immediate action?
output: Apply emergency miticide application (abamectin or spiromesifen) at maximum rate immediately, release massive predatory mite population (20-30 per m²), increase humidity to 75-80% slowing reproduction. Follow with second application in 3 days; scout daily for 2 weeks.

instruction: EMERGENCY: Thrips population outbreak, TSWV risk critical. Immediate control measures?
output: Apply emergency insecticide (spinosad or spinetoram) at maximum rate immediately, install blue sticky traps at 40 per 100m², release predatory mites Amblyseius swirskii at 100 per m². Remove all infected plants showing virus symptoms; repeat treatment every 3 days for 2 weeks.

instruction: EMERGENCY: Pythium outbreak, 60% plants wilting, roots brown and rotting. What to do urgently?
output: Stop irrigation immediately reducing frequency by 60%, apply emergency drench with mefenoxam at 2x recommended rate, improve drainage by adding channels, and remove severely affected plants. Apply hydrogen peroxide at 100ppm to remaining plants; expect 30% crop loss in severe outbreaks.

instruction: EMERGENCY: Hailstorm damaged 70% of fruit and leaves, extensive wounds. Immediate protocol?
output: Remove all severely damaged fruit and tissue immediately preventing disease entry, apply protective copper bactericide at 2g/L within 2 hours of damage, and increase air circulation reducing humidity below 70%. Monitor wounds daily for bacterial/fungal infection; expect 40-60% yield loss on current crop.

instruction: EMERGENCY: Substrate temperature at 35°C, root stress critical, plants wilting. Immediate cooling action?
output: Increase irrigation frequency immediately to every 30 minutes with cool water (15-18°C), apply overhead misting for evaporative cooling, and shade substrate surface with reflective mulch or white plastic. Reduce air temperature to 22°C maximum; expect 3-5 days recovery with possible root damage.

instruction: EMERGENCY: Whitefly population explosion, plants covered, TYLCV risk extreme. Urgent control?
output: Apply emergency insecticide (cyantraniliprole or spiromesifen) at maximum rate, install yellow sticky traps at 50 per 100m², release Encarsia formosa parasitoids at 10 per m². Remove severely infested plants, spray undersides thoroughly; repeat treatment every 4 days for 3 weeks.

instruction: EMERGENCY: Bacterial canker spreading rapidly, stem lesions oozing, 50% plants affected. Urgent action?
output: Remove and destroy all symptomatic plants immediately, disinfect tools with 10% bleach between every plant, apply copper bactericide at 2.5g/L to remaining plants. Quarantine greenhouse, reduce humidity to 65%, improve ventilation; consider crop termination if >70% infection rate.

instruction: EMERGENCY: Severe frost damage, leaves frozen and wilting, temperature was -2°C. Immediate response?
output: Do not disturb frozen tissue; allow slow thaw at ambient temperature, mist with water to moderate temperature change, and wait 24 hours to assess damage extent. Remove only completely dead tissue after 48 hours; apply protective fungicide preventing secondary infections on wounds.

instruction: EMERGENCY: Salt accumulation crisis, EC at 9 mS/cm throughout substrate, widespread wilting. Urgent leaching?
output: Implement emergency leaching with clean water at 400% pot volume immediately, continue until drainage EC drops below 3.5 mS/cm, and hand-water frequently next 48 hours. Apply calcium foliar spray at 0.5% preventing deficiency; expect 5-7 days recovery with possible leaf burn and fruit abortion.

instruction: EMERGENCY: Early blight outbreak, 70% defoliation, fruit exposed to sunscald. Immediate management?
output: Apply emergency fungicide rotation (chlorothalonil + azoxystrobin) at maximum rates immediately, remove all infected debris from greenhouse, and install temporary shade cloth at 30% over fruiting zones. Spray weekly for 3 weeks; consider early harvest of mature fruit; expect 50-70% yield loss.

instruction: EMERGENCY: Late blight detected, catastrophic spread potential, quarantine necessary. Immediate action?
output: Quarantine greenhouse immediately stopping all movement, apply emergency fungicide (chlorothalonil + mancozeb + metalaxyl) at maximum rates, remove all infected tissue within 2 hours. Reduce humidity to 65%, increase temperature to 28°C during day; consider crop destruction if infection >30% to protect other greenhouses.

instruction: EMERGENCY: Nitrogen deficiency crisis, all plants pale yellow, EC only 0.8 mS/cm. Immediate correction?
output: Apply emergency nitrogen as calcium nitrate foliar spray at 1% concentration immediately, increase base EC to 2.8 mS/cm using complete fertilizer, and provide supplemental ammonium nitrate at 50ppm N. Expect gradual greening over 7-10 days; fruit development will resume after 14 days.

instruction: EMERGENCY: Fusarium wilt spreading rapidly, 45% plants wilting, soilborne infection. Urgent containment?
output: Remove and destroy all symptomatic plants immediately with root balls, disinfect tools with bleach between plants, apply Trichoderma drench at 10⁹ cfu/ml to remaining plants. Increase substrate drainage, maintain temperature 22-24°C; plan crop termination and soil sterilization if infection exceeds 60%.

instruction: EMERGENCY: Control computer virus/malware, all systems malfunctioning, automation failed. Immediate action?
output: Switch to manual control mode immediately, disconnect infected computer from network, implement manual monitoring and adjustments every 2 hours. Call IT specialist for system restoration; maintain detailed manual logs until automation restored; typically requires 24-72 hours for complete recovery.

instruction: EMERGENCY: Rust mite outbreak, entire crop showing russeting, population extreme. Urgent miticide action?
output: Apply emergency sulfur spray at 7kg/ha when temperature <28°C, increase humidity to 75% slowing reproduction, and release predatory mites Amblyseius californicus at 50 per m². Spray every 3 days for 2 weeks; expect permanent fruit russeting but prevent further spread.

instruction: EMERGENCY: Calcium deficiency outbreak, 90% fruit showing blossom end rot. Urgent correction protocol?
output: Apply calcium chloride foliar spray at 0.6% immediately to all young fruit, increase irrigation frequency to every 90 minutes maintaining 68-72% substrate moisture, and reduce EC to 2.3 mS/cm. Remove affected fruit; expect 3-4 weeks before new fruit sets normally with 30-50% current yield loss.

instruction: EMERGENCY: Broad mite infestation, extreme leaf distortion, population exploding. Immediate control?
output: Apply emergency acaricide (abamectin at 1ml/L) immediately focusing on growing points, increase temperature briefly to 35°C for 2 hours if possible killing mites, and release predatory mites Amblyseius swirskii at 100 per m². Repeat treatment every 3 days for 2 weeks; expect 4-6 weeks recovery.

instruction: EMERGENCY: Cucumber mosaic virus outbreak, aphid vectors present, 40% plants infected. Urgent action?
output: Remove and destroy all symptomatic plants immediately, apply emergency insecticide (imidacloprid) controlling aphid vectors at maximum rate, install yellow sticky traps at 40 per 100m². Quarantine area, scout daily; if infection >60%, consider complete crop destruction preventing spread to other houses.

instruction: EMERGENCY: Pepino mosaic virus spreading rapidly, 65% plants infected, productivity declining. Urgent management?
output: Implement strict sanitation disinfecting tools with 5% milk solution between plants, remove worst infected plants, and optimize nutrition reducing stress (NPK 1:0.5:1.5). No cure exists; maintain production with aggressive sanitation for 8-12 weeks; plan early crop termination and complete disinfection.

instruction: EMERGENCY: Ammonium toxicity, all plants showing upward leaf curl, EC only 2.5. Immediate correction?
output: Stop all ammonium-based fertilizers immediately, switch to 100% nitrate-based nutrition, leach substrate with 200% pot volume clean water, and apply calcium nitrate foliar at 0.5%. Expect 7-10 days recovery; new growth will appear normal but existing cupped leaves remain symptomatic.

instruction: EMERGENCY: Root knot nematode population explosion, 70% plants with severe galling. Crisis response?
output: No effective chemical control in cropped greenhouse; maintain plants with increased fertilization (+25% N) compensating uptake loss, consider early harvest of marketable fruit. Plan immediate crop termination after harvest, steam sterilize or solarize substrate 60°C for 30 minutes, and use resistant rootstock for replanting.

instruction: EMERGENCY: Bacterial speck outbreak, 80% foliage with lesions, copper resistance detected. Urgent strategy?
output: Rotate to non-copper bactericide (streptomycin if permitted) at maximum rate, remove all heavily infected tissue, reduce humidity to 60%, and increase air circulation to 0.8 m/s. Spray every 5 days alternating products; expect 40-50% defoliation with significant yield impact.

instruction: EMERGENCY: Alternaria early blight, rapid defoliation 60% in 10 days, fungicide resistance suspected. Crisis management?
output: Rotate to different fungicide class immediately (azoxystrobin + difenoconazole at maximum rate), remove all infected leaves aggressively, reduce humidity to 65%, and improve air circulation. Spray every 4 days alternating chemistries; expect 70-80% defoliation and 50-70% yield loss.

instruction: EMERGENCY: Complete pollination failure, all new fruit hollow and seedless. Immediate corrective action?
output: Check bumblebee colony health immediately; if dead, source new colony within 24 hours and release at 1 hive per 1000m². Verify temperature 18-26°C during flowering, humidity 65-75%, and reduce nitrogen to N:K 1:1.5. Apply boron at 0.5ppm; expect 2-3 weeks before normal fruit set resumes.

instruction: EMERGENCY: Tomato chlorosis virus (ToCV), yellowing spreading rapidly, whitefly vectors present. Urgent response?
output: Remove all symptomatic plants immediately, apply emergency insecticide (cyantraniliprole) controlling whiteflies at maximum rate, install yellow sticky traps at 60 per 100m². Release Encarsia parasitoids at 10 per m²; if infection >50%, consider crop destruction preventing spread to adjacent greenhouses.

instruction: EMERGENCY: Ralstonia bacterial wilt confirmed, 35% plants collapsed, extremely contagious. Quarantine protocol?
output: Quarantine greenhouse immediately, remove and destroy all infected plants, disinfect all tools/equipment with bleach after each use, and consider complete crop destruction if infection >50%. No effective chemical control; steam sterilize substrate at 70°C for 60 minutes before replanting with resistant varieties.

instruction: EMERGENCY: Psyllid outbreak, all new growth cupped and twisted, bacterial disease vector present. Urgent integrated control?
output: Apply systemic insecticide (imidacloprid) immediately as soil drench for long-term control, spray with insecticidal soap for contact kill, install yellow sticky traps at 40 per 100m². Remove heavily damaged growth, monitor for bacterial diseases (Candidatus Liberibacter); expect 3-4 weeks for population suppression.

instruction: Daily light integral calculation method?
output: Sum instantaneous light readings (μmol/m²/s) over 24h, divide by 1,000,000. Target 15-20 mol/m²/day for tomatoes.

instruction: Pest population doubling time?
output: Calculate from weekly trap counts. Whitefly doubles every 18-21 days at 24°C.

instruction: Fruit set percentage optimization?
output: Calculate set fruits per 100 flowers. Target >90% with good climate and pollination.

instruction: Early blight severity tracking?
output: Score leaf infection 0-5 scale on 50 leaves. Economic threshold at mean score >2.5.

instruction: Predicting anthracnose from humidity?
output: Count hours with RH >90%. High risk when cumulative hours exceed 72 in 7-day period.

instruction: Predicting thrips generation time?
output: Calculate from daily temperature logs. Generation completes in 15 days at 25°C, 10 days at 30°C.

instruction: Computing heat stress hours?
output: Count hours above 32°C. Cumulative >20 hours/week reduces fruit set by 30-50%.
